awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I: Scalable Manufacturing Technology for Mobile Signal Penetrating Energy-Efficient Low-Emissivity Windows
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will be low-emissivity windows capable of allowing wireless signals to pass through. Presently, almost all commercial low-emissivity windows severely block mobile signals from entering buildings - a serious problem in today's world that demands fast and uninterrupted mobile connectivity. The proposed low-emissivity windows can be manufactured cost-competitively and significantly reduce the costs of installing indoor cellular aids such as routers and antennas. This technology will accelerate the further adoption of low-emissivity windows to reduce greenhouse gas emissions as well as support the further deployment of 5G technologies.

This SBIR Phase I project proposes to investigate scalable manufacturing of mobile, signal transmissive, low-emissivity windows by using lithographic deposition of photoresist structures on the glass substrate prior to low-emissivity vacuum coating. The project proposes to deposit photoresist structures with non-conductive spacers on glass substrate, reducing the low-emissivity coating’s electric conductivity that prevents wireless signal passthrough. Dielectric layers will be deposited over the sidewalls to form protective layers over the low-emissivity coatings to protect against oxidative corrosion. The width of the photoresist structures will range between 2 to 5 micrometers to minimize the degradation of low-emissivity coatings to less than 2%, to maintain thermal performance. After low-emissivity coating deposition, the non-planar spacers will subsequently collapse into the photoresist layer restoring low-emissivity coatings to their original planar position thereby rendering the photoresist structure invisible to the eye. Furthermore, the team will explore additional photoresist designs to address potential lighting diffractions that may form on the finished window.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Outcome Report

This NSF Phase I project successfully developed and validated an innovative lithography-based patterning technology that enables wireless signal penetration through low-emissivity (low-E) windows while maintaining their energy-efficient properties. This groundbreaking solution addresses a long-standing limitation of current low-E windows, which block mobile signals and hinder connectivity in buildings. By overcoming this challenge, the project paves the way for smarter, greener, and more connected environments.

The project achieved significant milestones aligned with its defined goals:

  • Prototype Development: Successfully created 3-inch diameter prototypes with a proprietary 4-micrometer lithography pattern structure. These prototypes allow mobile signal transmission through low-E coatings while maintaining excellent optical and thermal performance.
  • Optimization and Scaling: Completed 32 design iterations to optimize the pattern structure, size, density, and PVD coating parameters, ensuring compatibility with existing glass manufacturing processes and meeting production specifications. Scaled up production to 150 mm diameter prototypes, demonstrating feasibility for medium-scale product development.
  • Durability and Aesthetics: Post-patterned low-E glass exceeded industry durability standards, passing rigorous tests like high-temperature tempering and water boiling. Additionally, lithography patterns were rendered invisible under various lighting conditions, ensuring market-ready optical aesthetics.
  • Manufacturing Feasibility: Established a cost-effective lithography-based process adaptable to existing production lines, replacing unscalable laser-scribing methods and significantly reducing manufacturing costs for glass producers.

The project also made substantial progress in validating the commercial feasibility of the technology. Market research identified a clear demand, particularly among smaller commercial buildings and "green" buildings, where the technology can replace costly Distributed Antenna Systems (DAS) with a more efficient solution. Collaboration with global low-E glass manufacturers and telecommunications experts confirmed the technical feasibility and market readiness of the innovation. Additionally, two provisional patents and one non-provisional patent were filed to protect the technology.

This project demonstrated the initial viability of a transformative lithography-based technology that overcomes the longstanding challenge of low-E windows blocking mobile signals. By validating technical feasibility, product durability, optical aesthetics, and cost competitiveness, the project establishes a robust foundation for a scalable, energy-efficient, and mobile-connected glass solution.

The outcomes of this project have the potential to transform the next-generation glass and telecommunications industries, driving the adoption of smarter, greener, and more connected building environments.

 

 


Last Modified: 12/19/2024
Modified by: Guowen Ding

Image
  • Prototypes exposed to sunlight exhibited strong diffraction patterns without the LFI patent, whereas no observable diffraction patterns were seen with the LFI patent.

Outcome Report

This groundbreaking solution addresses a long-standing limitation of current low-E windows, which block mobile signals and hinder connectivity in buildings. By overcoming this challenge, the project paves the way for smarter, greener, and more connected environments.

Prototype      Development: Successfully created 3-inch diameter prototypes with a proprietary      4-micrometer lithography pattern structure. These prototypes allow mobile      signal transmission through low-E coatings while maintaining excellent      optical and thermal performance.

Scaled up production to 150 mm diameter prototypes,      demonstrating feasibility for medium-scale product development.

Additionally, lithography patterns were rendered invisible under various      lighting conditions, ensuring market-ready optical aesthetics.
Manufacturing      Feasibility: Established a cost-effective lithography-based process adaptable to      existing production lines, replacing unscalable laser-scribing methods and      significantly reducing manufacturing costs for glass producers.



The project also made substantial progress in validating the commercial feasibility of the technology. Market research identified a clear demand, particularly among smaller commercial buildings and "green" buildings, where the technology can replace costly Distributed Antenna Systems (DAS) with a more efficient solution. Collaboration with global low-E glass manufacturers and telecommunications experts confirmed the technical feasibility and market readiness of the innovation. Additionally, two provisional patents and one non-provisional patent were filed to protect the technology.


This project demonstrated the initial viability of a transformative lithography-based technology that overcomes the longstanding challenge of low-E windows blocking mobile signals. By validating technical feasibility, product durability, optical aesthetics, and cost competitiveness, the project establishes a robust foundation for a scalable, energy-efficient, and mobile-connected glass solution.


The outcomes of this project have the potential to transform the next-generation glass and telecommunications industries, driving the adoption of smarter, greener, and more connected building environments.
